summary: This is an email chain from October 2020 between an Assistant United States Attorney (AUSA) and an FBI Special Agent regarding the coordination of discovery evidence in the Epstein case. The AUSA is attempting to match device identifiers from two different spreadsheets related to evidence seized from searches in New York and the Virgin Islands.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: The sender of the main email, working to reconcile evidence identifiers for devices seized in the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Special Agent FBI New York Field Office Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking
persons.context: The sender of the earlier email, facilitating a connection for discovery-related questions regarding the Epstein case evidence.

connections.person1: Assistant United States Attorney Southern District of New York
connections.person2: Special Agent FBI New York Field Office Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking
connections.description: Communicating to coordinate and reconcile evidence tracking for the Epstein investigation discovery process.

events.title: Discovery Coordination Email

Special Agent FBI New York Field Office Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking

events.title: Initial Discovery Facilitation Email

personsInvolved: Special Agent FBI New York Field Office Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking

keyFacts: The document is an email chain concerning the post-investigative discovery phase of the Epstein case, specifically the tracking of seized digital evidence.
It lists numerous specific digital devices (hard drives, iMacs, thumb drives) seized from searches in New York and the Virgin Islands, identified by evidence numbers like NYCO24323.
The correspondence is explicitly 'SUBJECT TO PROTECTIVE ORDER,' indicating the sensitive nature of the evidence and ongoing legal proceedings.
The email shows coordination between the U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) and the FBI's Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking task force regarding evidence management.
